awd_titl_txt: ATD: Collaborative Research: Theory and Algorithms for Real-Time Threat Detection from Massive Data Streams
awd_abstract_narration:
National security interests demand a heightened awareness of the actions of various adversaries. This voracious appetite for information results in an overwhelming stream of spatiotemporal data. New mathematics is necessary to effectively manage this data deluge; this research project aims to develop new theory and algorithms for this cause. The approach is guided by the following abstract description of the threat detection problem: Given a massive stream of spatiotemporal data, the task is to maintain a slowly evolving model of "normalcy," any deviations from which are to be further investigated as potential threats. 

The project will focus on the following two objectives: (1) develop algorithms and optimal encodings to process massive data streams, and (2) develop fast certificates and guarantees for cutting-edge learning algorithms. To this end, the research aims to solve some of the big open problems in optimization, frame theory, and machine learning: (a) to quickly solve convex relaxations of NP-hard unsupervised learning problems from streaming data; (b) to construct optimal line packings, including the packings conjectured to exist by Zauner; (c) to find sub-linear a posteriori approximation certificates for NP-hard learning problems; (d) to explain the well-behaved optimization landscapes exhibited by generative adversarial networks; and (e) to develop fast, after-the-fact explanations for black-box classification, enabling well-informed human decision making.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
There were two types of outcomes from the research in this project: (1) the development of a mathematical theory of optimal encodings of data, and (2) the development of mathematical data science to obtain theoretical guarantees for machine learning.

For (1), we model the encoding problem in such a way that the goal is to measure data in vastly different directions. For example, given a 3-dimensional data point, we can measure the point by observing its location after projection onto a specified line through the origin. This suggests the natural problem of designing a collection of lines through the origin so that the pairwise interior angles are maximized. For example, an optimal arrangement of 6 lines through the origin of 3-dimensional space is realized by the diagonals of the regular icosahedron. In this project, we discovered many new families of optimal line packings using ideas involving symmetry, combinatorics, quantum mechanics, algebraic geometry, and convex programming.

For (2), we solved several fundamental problems in mathematical data science. For example, we obtained the first theoretical explanation for a certain geometric phenomenon that had been empirically observed when training deep neural networks. We also developed principled algorithms for both supervised and unsupervised machine learning tasks. Not only do these algorithms enjoy theoretical guarantees, they also provide state-of-the-art performance in various domains, such as classifying gene expression data or synthetic aperture radar imaging.

In addition to the above research outcomes, this project had substantial broader impacts. In particular, we developed future STEM professionals in the theory and application of signal processing and machine learning by mentoring them through the research process, and we broadened their technical communication skills by intensively workshopping their research presentations and write-ups.
